Reviews.Title: The "International" means they included a European electrical plug adapter not an upgrade to the electronics
Reviews.Author: bp
Reviews.Content: I have had one for a few years now and am looking to buy another one.  They are great.  I can afford a new fancy one but I like the size and durability of the defy. I haven't found anything that beats it for these features. The defy is well supported over at xda developers, google it.  It helps to be a little tech savy but it is more important to put the time in  to read and understand thoroughly how to upgrade the phone.  I have android jellybean on mine.  I wish there was something better out there for me but nothing beats the size, support and durability of this phone though I have never soaked it in the sink or Intentional dropped it. I've had chunks of plastic break off of the otter box skin/protector their not worth what they claim to be but the phone has survived climbing under cars in my pocket and general abuse. All Motorola defy MB525's have the same radios in them and there is nothing anymore international about this one that any other one that is unlocked for sale elsewhere.  I just talked to Motorola about it.  If you want a fancy big screen super fast latest and greatest phone this probably isn't for you.  I love it.  It's a legendary phone. Especially since I think it came out in 2010 and has a strong following. It helps if  you clear out the bloatware that Motorola adds and upgrade the software (this can void your warranty if you don't follow the directions but you can't permanently fry it from making a mistake upgrading it) .Update: After a lot of searching I found a picture of "International" kit and it seemed to include a European charging adapter. I think it might be helpful to explain the International component in the description. It took me a lot of searching to see if there was some sort of electronics in the phone that would make it work better abroad. Motorola no longer produces the original Defy so they had no information on the International part.  The new Defy plus is essentially the same as the original but they put a larger battery in it, overclocked the same old processor and updated the the android version. You can do the same thing with the original defy with a little work and even make it better.  Motorola isn't very good about updating their software I think they would rather just have you buy a new phone than be supportive.  But that's where the xda developers and similar sites really come together to make it a great and regularly updated phone.

Reviews.Content: Good smartphone with good features. Very reliable, The phone functionallity is excellent and the display is very bright. Some other features are very good and the phone caption is at the most top. The camera isn't as good but works well enough to get decent pictures. Solid structure, excellent screen response, very good battery life, has all what I need.Pros:Good screenGorilla glass screenWater resistantLong battery life

Reviews.Title: Disappointing smartphone
Reviews.Author: Robert S
Reviews.Content: The phone looks pretty and comes with some decent features, but in execution a lot of these break down.Flaws:- Google Maps crashes constantly.- Google Talk is completely integrated into the phone's OS rather than as an installable app - it can't be updated and is severely limited compared to the later versions out there.- Camera shutter button is on-screen only. With no *physical* button, taking pictures is tedious--taking self-pictures is almost impossible.- Power button is tiny and sometimes doesn't work. It has to be pressed in a specific way for it to work.- Motorola transfer software to PC is not user-friendly and crashes a lot.- Gallery - looking at picture folder thumbnails often freezes and doesn't unfreeze until you rotate the phone 90 degrees so the orientation updates. This happens regularly.- Adding app shortcuts to your home or other screen always takes 2 tries: the first time, it always stops responding.I'm rating this phone a 2 because as a working phone it works; as a smartphone, it's horrible.

Reviews.Title: still a great phone
Reviews.Author: rian
Reviews.Content: I lost my last mb525 defy overboard so bought another. the later model so far has not had any of the minor problems that others have reported such as frozen screen requiring power off on to fix. Also this one has inbuilt gps so it will run maps as a stand alone gps without internet connection.The first one fell  57cm onto a wooden floor and the screen went bung ( cost $80 to fix) so not very shock proof. Still all in all I like this new version just wish it had dual sim. one minor annoyance is the pre loaded cardio trainer app, it sets itself up every time the ph is powered on and drains the battery some so I have to go into app manager and force stop. not too much of a hassle.
